properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Campaspe River - Downstream of Rochester.

This Watch and Act message replaces the message published at 3pm Tuesday 9 January.

  • Moderate flooding slowly easing at Rochester.
  • In the 24 hours to 4 pm Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 20 mm have been recorded across the Campaspe River catchment, with no significant rainfall totals forecast for the next few days.
  • The main flood peak along the Campaspe River has now passed Rochester, where moderate flooding is occurring.
Campaspe River downstream of Rochester:
  • Moderate flooding is easing at Rochester Syphon. 
  • Minor flooding may develop at Echuca (Campaspe River gauge) Tuesday night.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels and flooding in rural areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Impacts will be less than the 2022 & 2011 flood events in the area downstream of Rochester.
Road Closures:
  • Multiple roads may become impacted due to floodwater. 
  • Sections of the Highway may become impacted by floodwater around Strathallan & Bamawm areas.
  • Before travelling please check information on road closures by visiting VicTraffic
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Sunday Creek at Tallarook 

  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1.50pm 9 January, 2024.
  • Minor flooding is easing along Sunday Creek at Tallarook.
  • No significant rainfall has been forecast for Tuesday.
  • Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees may still be present.
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.
  • Dry out and clean your home or business straight away.
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads or underpasses are flooded.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Seven Creeks to Euroa.

  • Rainfall totals up to approximately 20 mm have been observed across the Seven Creeks catchment since 9:00 am Monday.
  • A chance of showers and a thunderstorm is forecast for Tuesday, but forecast rainfall totals are not expected to significantly affect creek levels.
Seven Creeks to Euroa
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Seven Creeks to Euroa.
  • The Seven Creeks at Euroa is currently at 2.73 metres and steady, above the minor flood level. 
  • The Seven Creeks at Euroa may fall below the minor flood level (2.50 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 6:45 PM 8 January 2024.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act Message is for Rochester.

This warning replaces the Emergency Warning - Too Late to Leave published at 12pm Tuesday 9 January.

An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return.
 
  • The Campaspe River at Rochester town gauge peaked at 114.62 metres around 11:00 am Tuesday morning. 
  • The river fell below the major flood level (114.50 meters) Tuesday afternoon and is currently at 114.37 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. 
  • The Campaspe River at Rochester Town may fall below the moderate flood level (114.00 meters) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
  • The river level may fall below the minor flood level (113.00 meters) Wednesday morning.
  • It is still not safe to return to your property. 
  • Emergency Services will begin assessment of the affected area once the river has fallen below the Moderate flood level.
It is not safe for people to return to Rochester. If you have not evacuated, you should now shelter in the highest location possible.
If you have not already evacuated: 
  • Stay where you are and shelter in the highest location possible. 
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance. 
If you have already evacuated: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at the Echuca South Recreation Reserve (246 High Street, Echuca) Relief Centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 

This Watch and Act Message is likely to remain in place until the water has receded and assessment has been made that it is safe to return.

The next update is expected by 11am or as the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Water Authority pumps have been turned back on in the Rochester township.
  • Emergency Services will provide alternative options for water if required.  
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Multiple roads have been closed due to floodwater. 
  • For more information on road closures go to VicTraffic
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 11:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Emergency Warning to evacuate, following flooding at Low lying parts of Yea has been lifted.
  • It is now Safe to Return.
  • Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees may still be present.
  • Floodwater that affected low lying parts of Yea has mostly cleared, but impacts of flooding may still remain. 
This Advice replaces the Watch and Act message issued at 10.33 9 January, 2024. 
It is now safe to return the evacuated area to assess impacts as the threat is reduced. Be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area. 
  
You should avoid Webster Street between Craigie and Snodgrass Streets as well as Craigie Street west of Webster Street due to water still over the roads.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads or underpasses are flooded.
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees. 
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters.
If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.
Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area:
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area.
  • River heights in your area are likely to remain high in the coming days.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning issued for this flood.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.

  • Widespread moderate flooding is developing along the Bendigo Creek downstream Minto. 
  • Significant rainfall occurred over the previous few days in the Bendigo Creek Catchment. 
  • These floodwaters will move downstream over Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.
  • On Tuesday to Wednesday, these floodwaters will affect locations including Tandarra, Dingee, Prairie and Mitiamo.
  • On Wednesday to Thursday, these floodwaters is likely to affect locations including Mitiamo, Pyramid Hill and Kow Swamp. 
This Watch and Act replaces the previous Watch and Act message published at 8:10pm Monday 8 January, with a reduced warning area based on potential flood impact.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling:  
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
Impacts in your area:  
  • A small number of properties are likely to be impacted and possibly become isolated.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Multiple roads have been closed due to floodwater. 
  • Portion of the Bendigo Pyramid Road between Raywood & Tandarra remains closed. For more information on road closures go to VicTraffic
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbotsford
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbotsford.

The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 27 mm in the upper part of the catchment and about 26 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Monday 08 January 2024. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment for Tuesday 09 January 2024.

Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbottsford:
The level of the Yarra River at Templestowe is currently at 3.63 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (3.50 metres) and falling. It peaked last night at 4.95 metres, well below the Moderate Flood Level. It is expected to drop back below the Minor Flood Level later this afternoon.

The level of the Yarra River at Heidelberg is currently at 7.68 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (6.00 metres) and falling slowly. It peaked early this morning at 7.78 metres and is expected to remain above the Minor Flood Level until tomorrow evening (Wednesday 9 January).

The level of the Yarra River at Alphington is currently at 4.06 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (3.00 metres) and rising slowly. It is expected to peak well below the Moderate Flood Level later today.

The level of the Yarra River at Abbotsford is currently at 4.12 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (2.70 metres) and rising slowly. It is expected to peak well below the Moderate Flood Level later today.

Minor flooding in the Yarra and Watts River catchments is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Dont swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Goulburn River upstream of Lake Eildon
properties.webBody:
A Final Flood Watch has been issued for the Goulburn River upstream of Lake Eildon.

  • Rainfall risk has eased. 
  • Flooding is no longer expected in the Goulburn River upstream of Lake Eildon.
  • In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday, rainfall totals up to 96 mm were observed across parts of the Flood Watch area. Catchments are moderately wet to very wet following recent rainfall. 
  • No significant flood-producing rainfall is forecast for the next few days. A chance of showers and thunderstorms remains, but forecast rainfall totals are not expected to significantly affect river and creek levels. 
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 5:29 PM 8 January 2024. 
The threat of flooding is reduced. You can now return to normal activity, but be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning issued for this flood.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek:

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT THOMS BRIDGE OVERNIGHT TUESDAY, WITH POSSIBLE MODERATE PEAK DURING WEDNESDAY

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday, rainfall totals of approximately 10-25 mm, with isolated higher totals of 40-75 mm, were recorded across the Latrobe River catchment. No significant rainfall has been recorded since then.

Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek:

Moderate flooding is likely along the Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek.

The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is currently at 4.20 metres and rising, above the minor flood level (4.00m). The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (5.00 m) overnightTuesday into Wednesday. The river level may peak near 5.10 metres during Wednesday.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Bunyip River to Iona.

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging 30 mm since 09:00 AM Monday 08 January 2024. The Western Port catchment has recorded rainfall averaging 21 mm for the same period. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment Tuesday 09 January 2024.

Water levels of the Bunyip River at various locations have risen in response to the rain.

Bunyip River to Iona:
The level of the Bunyip River at Iona is currently at 3.51 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (2.10 metres) and falling. It peaked overnight at 4.76 metres, just below the Moderate Flood Level of 5.00 metres. It is expected to drop below Minor Flood Level again by tomorrow afternoon.

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn will remain closed to traffic until the level in the river drops below Minor Flood Level again.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.

properties.webBody:
This Warning is being issued for areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.

  • A landslide has occurred in the area near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.
  • The landslide is approximately 40 metres wide and 70 metres long.
Stay safe by avoiding damaged buildings, fallen trees and powerlines, blocked or damaged roads. Be aware of other hazards caused by the landslide.
What you should do:

If another landslide occurs, act quickly:
  • If you are outside during a landside, move quickly and keep clear of embankments, trees, powerlines and poles.
  • If you are inside, move to the part of building that is furthest away from the approaching landslide and take shelter under a table or bench.
Avoid the area:
  • Stay away from the impacted area to allow emergency services to help affected communities.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Driving:
  • Plan your trip in advance - travel may take longer due to closed roads and poor driving conditions.
Impacts in your area:
The landslide has resulted in:
  • The Mount Dandenong Tourist Road is closed between Churchill Drive and Mast Gully Road and may remain closed for some time. For more information on road closures go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Properties have been impacted. 
  • Fallen power lines.
  • Fallen trees and branches.
  • Dangerous road conditions.
  • Work is being undertaken to reconnect power. 
  • Public Transport has been impacted by the landslide. You should check www.ptv.vic.gov.au/live-travel-updates for the latest updates on services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#viclandslide).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Poowong, Loch and Nyora residents. 
  • The tap water in Poowong, Loch and Nyora is not safe to drink without boiling first. 
  • A boil water advisory has been issued following reports of contaminated water in the Poowong-Loch-Nyora water supply system.
  • Consumption of unboiled water can cause gastro-like symptoms. If you experience any of these symptoms, please contact your GP and inform your GP of this advisory.
  • This is an updated Advice message that replaces the Advice issued at 9:53 am on Friday 5 January 2024.
If you live or work within Poowong, Loch and Nyora, you must boil tap water before drinking. Or drink bottled water.
What you should do:  
  • Boil water before drinking it, or drink bottled water.  
  • Boil water for washing and preparing food, preparing beverages, making ice and for preparing baby formula. 
  • Boil water for brushing teeth.
To ensure water is safe to drink you should: 
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable, variable temperature kettles should be set to boil).
  • Allow water to cool before use.
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use.
  • Be careful when boiling water to prevent scalding or burns. 
It is safe to use unboiled water for:
  • Washing your hands
  • Cleaning dishes - use hot soapy water and let them air dry before using them again or use a dishwasher. 
  • Washing clothes.
  • Showering and bathing in. Young children should be given a sponge bath to avoid them accidentally swallowing the water. 
  • Garden watering. If you grow fruits and vegetables then they will need to be washed with cooled boiled water before you eat them.
  • Flushing toilets.
For health advice:
  • Call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24 or see your doctor if you require medical advice.
Impacts in your area: 
  • South Gippsland Water advises customers in Poowong, Loch and Nyora to boil their drinking water until further notice. 
  • Water trailers are available at Nyora Recreational Reserve, Poowong Recreational Reserve, Main Street Loch and Speight Street in Loch from 9:30 am on 04/01/2024.
  • Further details can be found at https://www.sgwater.com.au/alerts
This message was issued by Department of Health.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Incident Location: Poowong, Loch and Nyora
Issue Date: Monday 08 January 2024, 12:21 pm
Next Update: Thursday 11 January 2024, 03:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32092/moreinfo

This Advice is being issued for Poowong, Loch and Nyora residents. 
- The tap water in Poowong, Loch and Nyora is not safe to drink without boiling first. 
- A boil water advisory has been issued following reports of contaminated water in the Poowong-Loch-Nyora water supply system.
- Consumption of unboiled water can cause gastro-like symptoms. If you experience any of these symptoms, please contact your GP and inform your GP of this advisory.
- This is an updated Advice message that replaces the Advice issued at 9:53 am on Friday 5 January 2024.


If you live or work within Poowong, Loch and Nyora, you must boil tap water before drinking. Or drink bottled water.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte.

The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 27 mm in the upper part of the catchment and about 26 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Monday 08 January 2024. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment for Tuesday 09 January 2024.

Water levels of the Yarra River and Watts Rivers at various locations are rising in response to the rain.

Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte:

The level of the Yarra River at Yarra Glen is currently at 4.40 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (4.10 metres) and steady. It is expected to remain above the Minor Flood Level for the next few days.

The level of the Yarra River at Warrandyte is currently at 2.42 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (3.00 metres) and falling. It peaked at 3.04 metres last night just above the Minor Flood Level.

Minor flooding in the Yarra and Watts River catchments is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT D/S LAKE GLENMAGGIE

In the 24 hours to 1 pm Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 70 mm were recorded across the Macalister River catchment. No significant rainfall has been observed since 1 pm Tuesday and no significant rainfall is forecast.

Southern Rural Water have advised that releases from Lake Glenmaggie will be maintained between 10,000ML/d and 11,000 ML/d through to Wednesday, above the minor flood level at the downstream gauge.

Warnings will be updated as further information on flows from the storage arrive.

Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie

Minor flooding is occurring along the Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

The Macalister River D/S Lake Glenmaggie is currently at 3.05 metres and steady, above the minor flood level (2.60 metres). With releases from Lake Glenmaggie, the Macalister River at the Lake Glenmaggie downstream gauge is expected to remain near 3.10 metres overnight Tuesday into Wednesday, with minor flooding.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground. 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton
This Advice replaces the Flood Watch issued at 6.51 pm today. 
 
Minor flooding may occur along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.
MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT MURCHISON OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY, WITH POSSIBLE MODERATE PEAK AROUND 10.5M LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON FROM THURSDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT SEYMOUR

  • No significant rainfall has been forecast for Tuesday across the Goulburn River catchment.
  • Releases from Lake Eildon have increased to 3000 ML/day.
Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton:
  • Minor flooding may occur along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.
  • The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 4.40 metres and steady, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge may exceed the minor flood level (9.00 m) during Friday. 
  • Further rises are possible as upstream flows arrive.
Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour:
  • Moderate flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour. 
  • Moderate flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River at Trawool.
  • The Goulburn River downstream of Lake Eildon is currently at 1.64 metres and steady, below the minor flood level (3.00 m). 
  • The Goulburn River downstream of  Lake Eildon is expected to remain below the minor flood level (3.00 m).

The Goulburn River at Seymour: 
  • Peaked at 6.80 metres around 04:00 pm Monday 08 January, just below the major flood level of 7.00 metres and is currently at 5.75 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. 
  • A renewed rise is expected along the Goulburn River at Seymour during Tuesday afternoon. The river may peak near 5.90 metres Tuesday evening, with moderate flooding (moderate flood level 5.20 m)
Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:
  • Moderate flooding is likely along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton.
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 9.85 metres and rising, with minor flooding. 
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (10.20 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
  • The river level may peak around 10.50 m Wednesday late morning, with moderate flooding.
The Goulburn River at Shepparton:
  • Is currently at 7.11 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton is likely to exceed the minor flood level (9.50 m) Wednesday afternoon. 
  • The river level may reach the moderate flood level (10.70 m) from Thursday morning. 
  • Further rises are possible as upstream floodwater arrives. The situation is being closely monitored and warnings will be updated as required.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Low lying riverside Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds may be closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater. For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
For health information and support contact the below organisations: 
Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpline on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison.
This Watch and Act for Moderate level flood message replaces the warning issued at 6.50 pm today. 

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT MURCHISON OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY, WITH POSSIBLE MODERATE PEAK AROUND 10.5M LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON FROM THURSDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT SEYMOUR

  • No significant rainfall has been forecast for Tuesday across the Goulburn River catchment.
  • Releases from Lake Eildon have increased to 3000 ML/day.
Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison:
  • Moderate flooding is likely along the Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison.
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 9.85 metres and rising, with minor flooding. 
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (10.20 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
  • The river level may peak around 10.50 m Wednesday late morning, with moderate flooding.
The Goulburn River at Shepparton: 
  • Is currently at 7.11 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton is likely to exceed the minor flood level (9.50 m) Wednesday afternoon. 
  • The river level may reach the moderate flood level (10.70 m) from Thursday morning. 
  • Further rises are possible as upstream floodwater arrives. 
  • The situation is being closely monitored and warnings will be updated as required.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground if still safe to do.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 

If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways. 

If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
At the estimated peak of 10.5 m:
  • This flood may be similar to the Sept 1993 flood level 
  • A small number of properties are likely to be impacted and possibly become isolated in the Old Weir Road area. 
  • Low-lying rural properties upstream and downstream of Murchison likely to be flooded which may require the moving of stock and equipment to higher ground and the closure of some local roads and the Campbells Bend camping and fishing spots north of the Bridge.
  • At 10.15 m, during the 2010 flood, the River Haven caravan park residents and caravans were relocated to higher ground.
Main Road Closure
  • The Bendigo-Murchison Road (C345) is closed between Colbinabbin and Rushworth. Diversions via Stanhope and Corop.  Speed limits are also in place along this road due to road surface damage west of the Cattanach Canal.


This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

This Watch and Act for Moderate level flood message replaces the warning issued at 6.50 pm today. 

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT MURCHISON OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY, WITH POSSIBLE MODERATE PEAK AROUND 10.5M LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON FROM THURSDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT SEYMOUR

- No significant rainfall has been forecast for Tuesday across the Goulburn River catchment.
- Releases from Lake Eildon have increased to 3000 ML/day. 
Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison:
- Moderate flooding is likely along the Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison.
- The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 9.85 metres and rising, with minor flooding. 
- The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (10.20 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
- The river level may peak around 10.50 m Wednesday late morning, with moderate flooding.
The Goulburn River at Shepparton: 
- Is currently at 7.11 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 
- The Goulburn River at Shepparton is likely to exceed the minor flood level (9.50 m) Wednesday afternoon. 
- The river level may reach the moderate flood level (10.70 m) from Thursday morning. 
- Further rises are possible as upstream floodwater arrives. 
- The situation is being closely monitored and warnings will be updated as required.


Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/01/2024 04:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour.
This update replaces the Watch and Act message issued at 5.38pm 9 January, 2024. 

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT MURCHISON OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY, WITH POSSIBLE MODERATE PEAK AROUND 10.5M LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING
MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON FROM THURSDAY MORNINGMODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT SEYMOUR

No significant rainfall has been forecast for Tuesday across the Goulburn River catchment.

Releases from Lake Eildon have increased to 3000 ML/day.

Moderate flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour. 
Moderate flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River at Trawool.

The Goulburn River downstream of Lake Eildon 
  • Is currently at 1.64 metres and steady, below the minor flood level (3.00 m). 
  • The Goulburn River downstream of Lake Eildon is expected to remain below the minor flood level (3.00 m).

The Goulburn River at Seymour 
  • Peaked at 6.80 metres around 04:00 pm Monday 08 January, just below the major flood level of 7.00 metres and is currently at 5.75 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. 
  • A renewed rise is expected along the Goulburn River at Seymour during Tuesday afternoon. The river may peak near 5.90 metres Tuesday evening, with moderate flooding (moderate flood level 5.20 m)
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Check out the SES Seymour Local Flood Guide for more detailed information: https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/mitchell-shire-council
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home may still occur in some locations.
  • A small number of properties may still be be impacted and possibility become isolated in low lying areas close to the river.
  • Flooding is still likely to affect all or part of the following streets: Emily St, Tierney St, Lesley St, Tallarook St, Wallis St, High St, Elizabeth St, Butler St, Alexander St, Edward St, Station St, Tristan St, Hanna St, Jubilee St, Industrial Court.
  •  Kings Park and local river caravan parks may still be impacted.
At 5.2-5.9 m flood height 
  • Tierney, High and Wallis Streets may still be flooded. 
  • Emily Street stormwater may still be backed up around roads and gardens. 
At 6.1 m flood height (just above the predicted 5.9 m)
  • The river Floodplain from the Hume Freeway to the Goulburn Valley Highway may still be flooded.
Main Road closures: 
  • Goulburn Valley Highway (B340) closed at Whiteheads Creek
  • Upper Goulburn Road (C383)
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
Community meeting:
  • There will be a community meeting to be held at 4pm Wednesday 10 January, 2024 at the Seymour Recovery Hub, 4 Guild Street, Seymour
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Campaspe River - Barnadown to Rochester.

This Moderate flood message replaces the Move to Higher Ground message published at 3pm Tuesday 9 January.

  • Moderate flooding slowly easing at Rochester.
  • In the 24 hours to 4 pm Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 20 mm have been recorded across the Campaspe River catchment, with no significant rainfall totals forecast for the next few days.
  • The main flood peak along the Campaspe River has now passed Rochester, where moderate flooding is occurring.
Campaspe River Barnadown to Rochester:

  • Moderate flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River Barnadown to Rochester. 
  • Moderate flooding is occurring at Campaspe Weir.
  • The Campaspe River at Rochester town gauge peaked at 114.62 metres around 11:00 am Tuesday morning. 
  • The river fell below the major flood level (114.50 meters) Tuesday afternoon and is currently at 114.37 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. 
  • The Campaspe River at Rochester Town may fall below the moderate flood level (114.00 meters) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
  • The river level may fall below the minor flood level (113.00 meters) Wednesday morning.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Be prepared to move household items to higher ground, on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Water Authority pumps have been turned back on in the Rochester township.
  • Emergency Services will provide alternative options for water if required.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. 
  • For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
Road Closures:
  • Multiple roads have been closed due to floodwater. 
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • For more information on road closures go to VicTraffic

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app

  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

- Moderate flooding slowly easing at Rochester.
- In the 24 hours to 4 pm Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 20 mm have been recorded across the Campaspe River catchment, with no significant rainfall totals forecast for the next few days.
- The main flood peak along the Campaspe River has now passed Rochester, where moderate flooding is occurring.
Campaspe River Barnadown to Rochester:

- Moderate flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River Barnadown to Rochester. 
- Moderate flooding is occurring at Campaspe Weir.
- The Campaspe River at Rochester town gauge peaked at 114.62 metres around 11:00 am Tuesday morning. 
- The river fell below the major flood level (114.50 meters) Tuesday afternoon and is currently at 114.37 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. 
- The Campaspe River at Rochester Town may fall below the moderate flood level (114.00 meters) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. 
- The river level may fall below the minor flood level (113.00 meters) Wednesday morning.


Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton.
This Watch and Act message replaces the warning issued at 6.44 pm today.

MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON FROM THURSDAY MORNING

MODERATE FLOODING LIKELY AT MURCHISON OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY, WITH POSSIBLE MODERATE PEAK AROUND 10.5M LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT SEYMOUR

  • No significant rainfall has been forecast for Tuesday across the Goulburn River catchment.
  • Releases from Lake Eildon are increasing to 3000 ML/day during Tuesday

Goulburn River at Shepparton 
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton is currently at 7.11 metres and rising, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton is likely to exceed the minor flood level (9.50 m) Wednesday afternoon. 
  • The river level may reach the moderate flood level (10.70 m) from Thursday morning. 
  • Further rises are possible as upstream floodwater arrives. The situation is being closely monitored and warnings will be updated as required.
Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 9.85 metres and rising, with minor flooding. 
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (10.20 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. The river level may peak around 10.50 m Wednesday late morning, with moderate flooding.
Prepare for flooding now. 
Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.
What you should do:

  • Check out the NEW SES Shepparton-Mooroopna-Kialla Local Flood Guide for more detailed information: https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Follow your emergency plan and locate your emergency kit, if you have one.
  • Be prepared to move household items to higher ground, on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations. A small number of properties are likely to be impacted and possibility become isolated.
  • Check out the NEW SES Shepparton-Mooroopna-Kialla Local Flood Guide for more detailed information: https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
At Moderate flood level 10.70 m :
  • River end parts of Watt Road and Raftery Road will start to flood.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Bunyip River downstream of Iona.

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging 30 mm since 09:00 AM Monday 08 January 2024. The Western Port catchment has recorded rainfall averaging 21 mm for the same period. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment Tuesday 09 January 2024.

Water levels of the Bunyip River at various locations are rising in response to the rain.

Bunyip River downstream of Iona:
The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 4.52 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres) and falling. It peaked overnight at 4.92 metres, just below the Moderate Flood Level of 5.00 metres. It is expected to remain above the Minor Flood Level for the next few days.

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn will remain closed to traffic until the level in the river drops below Minor Flood Level again.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Some bicycle and walking tracks will be unpassable at this level.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Dont swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 10:10 AM 2 January 2024. 
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2024 02:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
